Hi Ken, 

I am happy that you like my demo. This particular experiment was =
set 
up to answer some questions I had in mind. The first one is obvious, 
=
is there a geometric regularity in the predator/prey task that 
HyperNEAT c=
an possibly exploit. And there is. I can see some 
meaningful behaviors eme=
rging with HyperNEAT as early as the 4th or 
5th generation. My next questi=
on was, what is the difference between 
the indirect encoding and the direc=
t encoding. Let me make it more 
clear. In your experiments in the robot du=
el domain, both robot NNs 
are encoded directly and complexifying. They ela=
borate on previous 
strategies by incrementally adding more structure, righ=
t? 
What about HyperNEAT, does it preserve the same dynamics, where the 
CP=
PNs complexify but the substrate is fixed? Does it lead to endless 
alterat=
ion of strategies instead of elaboration? I can predict that 
HyperNEAT can=
 discover some complex connectivity patterns between 
hidden nodes to devel=
op some kind of "intelligent" behavior, but is 
that limited? 
Well this qu=
estion is still not answered because, as you mentioned, 
the predator/prey =
task is too easy to learn, though there is room for 
the predator and prey =
to learn tricks to fool each other. For example 
the prey can learn to hide=
 behind walls, etc. 
Yes I compared it to direct encoding NEAT and generall=
y I can conclude 
that HyperNEAT develops strategies faster. Especially in =
the case of 
many many inputs. Scaling works as well, but it is not perfect=
. 
Let me tell you about the source code. Unfortunately the core NEAT 
libr=
ary I wrote and use is locked under an NDA but it is equivalent to 
the rtN=
EAT modification I released with the NEVH project. The 
visualization routi=
nes are basically the same there, there is nothing 
new at all. But I can r=
elease the source code for the demos 
themselves. Please ask me about any d=
etails, I will be happy to help 
anyone. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter, thanks for this Hype=
rNEAT coevolution demo.  I see some
> interesting behaviors evolving, but I=
 am curious about your own
> conclusions?  What did you learn from this exp=
eriment?  Did you try
> comparing it to regular NEAT in the same domain?  I=
 am not sure
> whether the difference would be great since I am not sure if=
 this 
task
> is sufficiently complex to exhibit a significant difference b=
etween
> the methods.  That is, there is probably only so good that you can=
 
get
> before new skills stop really mattering in this domain.
> 
> By the=
 way, do you plan releasing source code for your various
> experiments and =
AI code?  It seems like you have a nice system set 
up
> and other people m=
ight like tinkering with it.  I especially like 
the
> real-time CPPN/subst=
rate displays.
> 
> ken
>
